author: @violet_broregarde
text: Why are you sending raw passwords over the wire? You're putting yourself at risk for a man-in-the-middle attack. Encrypt them on the client side before sending them.

text: Hi  Sentdex,  I am storing some info in MySQL DB using a sha256_crypt method, now I want to decrypt that value but I am not able to find the way. could you please help me... author: @irzelindojoaquim8277
text: Hi,  nice video The password will be sent via http POST method. to the server. if there is somebody in the middle and finds out the username and password of the client before it being encrypted by the server.   How can we avoid that also?

author: @janekmuric
text: Friendly warning: All SHA hash algorithms are now horribly out of date. What is recommended now is PBKDF2 and bcrypt.   Keep in mind that they are recommended at the time of posting this comment, so your best bet is to Google what algorithm you should use.

author: @bainadeashish
text: I am getting error for this small script:  from passlib.hash import sha256_crypt  password = sha256_crypt.encrypt("abc")  with open('pwd.txt', 'a') as f:     f.write(password)     f.write('\n')   with open('pwd.txt', 'r') as f:     first_line = f.readline()  print first_line,password print(sha256_crypt.verify("abc", password)) print(sha256_crypt.verify("abc", first_line)) ------ error ValueError: malformed sha256_crypt hash (checksum must be exactly 43 chars)

author: @ShivamChopra91
text: if anyone is getting errors while importing sha256_crypt, try this : from passlib.handlers.sha2_crypt import sha256_crypt
